Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Neuroimaging and Hormonal Analyses of Gender and Interindividual Differences in Competitive Choices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Previous work has shown significant gender differences in the likelihoood to compete, with men being about twice as willing as women. More recent work suggests that these differences are driven by hormonal levels within an individual over time. This proposal will assess the relationship between hormones and both competitive and cooperative choices in a larger sample of men and women. Estrogen, progesterone (in women) and testosterone (in men and women) will be measured. A second study will add neuroimaging to test the hypothesis that gender and individual differences in competitive/cooperative choices result from hormonal modulation of activity in the brain's reward areas.

In terms of broader impacts, the results showing that men are more willing to compete than women have been and have been offered as a partial explanation for gender differences in outcomes in earnings and careers, including the scarcity of women in top executive and academic positions. This research will shed light on the causes of this result, and will help to evaluate the desirability and design of policy interventions to address such differences. A better understanding of the reasons for the wide variations in competitive behavior can also help individuals make more informed decisions about education and careers on their own as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In examining the sources of gender differences to compete, we have focused on developing a paradigm that could be implemented in an fMRI scanner such that we could link hormonal and behavioral data with brain activations. To attain this goal we developed a behavioral study that has allowed us to elicit competitive choices of ninety subjects whose data could be used in competitions within an fMRI scanner. Using data from this behavioral experiment, we are in the process of running a large-scale fMRI study where we assess the competitive choices and hormonal data of thirty males and sixty females and correlate differences with the fMRI data.

Data collection should be complete within the next six-months (a delay occurred due to access to the fMRI scanner being limited until the Sprin of 2013). After the fMRI data is collected we believe that we will have gained a better understanding of the mechanisms behind gender differences for competitive behaviors. Thus, far our study design has also provided a methodological contribution to the social science fields because we have found a way to replicate gender differences for competitions in an fMRI scanner environment. These outcomes were part of the intellectual merit that we had proposed in our study and we seem to be on course to attain them.

Furthermore, the broader impact of our study should allow us to better understand inter and intra-individual differences regarding preferences for competitions. Currently, in our preliminary results, we find that female choices seem to be linked to both baseline levels and fluctuations in hormones related to the menstrual cycle while male choices to compete seem unrelated to hormones including testosterone. Though we currently have a small sample that we are studying, we hope to learn and understand more about these choices as we near closer to the end of our data collection stage in the upcoming weeks.
